questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Office 365 subscription that contains a user named User1.
You need to ensure that User1 can view Analytics & reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to User1?

discussion.content:
B (SfB admin) is correct. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/get-started-with-teams-monitor-usage-and-feedback 
This link mentioned "To view these reports, you must be a global admin in Microsoft 365 or Office 365, Teams service admin, or Skype for Business admin"
Skype for business is dead..

Selected Answer: C
Reports Reader
Users with this role can view usage reporting data and the reports dashboard in Microsoft 365 admin center and the adoption context pack in Fabric and Power BI. A user assigned to the Reports Reader role can access only relevant usage and adoption metrics. They don't have any admin permissions to configure settings or access the product-specific admin centers like Exchange.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#reports-reader

How to access the reports
To access the reports, you must be assigned one of the following roles:
Teams or Skype for Business administrator. (might be deprecated) 
Global reader (only tenant-level aggregate and no per-user or team data).
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference#how-to-access-the-reports

Selected Answer: C
B or c according to https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference

So least privilege is C

Selected Answer: C
To access the reports, you must be assigned one of the following roles:
Teams or Skype for Business administrator.
Global reader (only tenant-level aggregate and no per-user or team data).

Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference

Selected Answer: D
global reader would give you permissions to read all of Entra, definitely not least privilege. Not sure, why this would not be Reports reader.

Selected Answer: D
To ensure that User1 can view Analytics & reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center while adhering to the principle of least privilege, you should assign User1 the D. Reports reader role.

The Reports reader role is specifically designed to give users read-only access to usage reports and analytics in the Microsoft 365 admin center and Teams admin center. This role allows User1 to view reports without granting broader administrative privileges that are not necessary for viewing analytics.

Selected Answer: D
Both options C (Global reader) and D (Reports reader) have their merits, and the choice depends on the specific requirements and desired level of access. Here's a summary:

- **Global reader (C)**: Provides access to tenant-level aggregate data without exposing per-user or per-team details. Suitable for general analytics and reports across the entire organization.
- **Reports reader (D)**: Specifically grants access to view Teams-related reports within the Microsoft Teams admin center. Focused on Teams usage and activity.

Considering your explanation, if broader analytics access is needed while still restricting per-user or per-team details, option D (Reports reader) would indeed be the better choice.

Selected Answer: C
As per MS articles in 2024, it should be C - Global Reader.

Skype for buisness admin does not exists.
Report reader cannot access - Analytics report
Hence it should be global reader 

Reference - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. Among the choices, D represents the least privilege, and I confirmed this on my test tenant. I assigned the role using Entra ID, and the user now has access to analytics and reports.

I'll go with C as the correct answer. Keyword used "least privilige"

How to access the reports
To access the reports, you must be assigned one of the following roles:

Global administrator.
Teams or Skype for Business administrator.
Global reader (only tenant-level aggregate and no per-user or team data).

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference

Looks like C as least privilege is 'Global reader'. 
(Question states that you only need to view analytics and reports.)

is these one sure

Corect answer is B because Teams admin center - Global Reader cannot read Teams lifecycle, Analytics & reports, IP phone device management, and App catalog. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-US/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference?WT.mc_id=365AdminCSH#global-reader

Selected Answer: D
To ensure that User1 can view Analytics & reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center using the principle of least privilege, you should assign the "Reports reader" role to User1. This role provides read-only access to the reports and analytics data in the Microsoft Teams admin center without granting additional administrative privileges. This way, User1 can view the necessary information without having unnecessary administrative powers.
the correct response is D

Selected Answer: B
In the documentation link https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/get-started-with-teams-monitor-usage-and-feedback 
is clear :

comments.content:
Global Reader role has the following limitations:
Teams admin center - Global Reader cannot read Teams lifecycle, Analytics & reports, IP phone device management, and App catalog.

To view these reports, you must be a global admin in Microsoft 365 or Office 365, Teams service admin, or Skype for Business admin

discussion.content: Awnser: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference#how-to-access-the-reports

Selected Answer: D
D. Report Reader

Explanation: To allow User1 to view analytics and reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center, it's necessary to assign the Report Reader role.
This role provides read-only access to usage and activity reports for Teams and its associated services, without granting editing or administrative access.
The assignment of the Report Reader role follows the principle of least privilege, ensuring that the user has access only to the necessary information for their specific role.

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. Reports reader.

To ensure that User1 can view Analytics & reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center, you need to assign the appropriate role to the user. The principle of least privilege states that you should only grant the minimum permissions necessary to perform a task. In this case, the user does not need full administrative permissions, but only needs the ability to view Analytics & reports.

The Reports reader role is the appropriate role to assign to User1. This role allows the user to view reports and analytics data in the Microsoft Teams admin center. It does not allow the user to make any changes or perform any administrative tasks.

Selected Answer: B
According to MS: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference

To access the reports (Analytics & reports), you must be assigned one of the following roles:
Global administrator.
Teams or Skype for Business administrator.
Global reader (only tenant-level aggregate and no per-user or team data)

comments.content: CORRECTION: Just tested in my lab. Report Reader is the least privileged role in the list (can view 4 Usage Reports in Analytics & Reports.

requirement is use to least privilege's , So both Global reader and Skype for Business admin can read the reports but the least privilege's is Global reader as it can only read but not update anything.

Teams analytics & reports (Microsoft Teams admin center)
Teams reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center give you insights into how Teams is used in your organization. Use the reports to get a view into Teams usage, user activity, and device usage across your organization.

To view these reports, you must be a global admin in Microsoft 365 or Office 365, Teams service admin, or Skype for Business admin. Go to the Microsoft Teams admin center, in the left navigation, select Analytics & reports, and then under Report, choose the report you want to run.

discussion.content:
It is not D.
Users with this role can view usage reporting data and the reports dashboard in Office 365 admin center and the adoption context pack in Power BI. Additionally, the role provides access to sign-on reports and activity in Azure AD and data returned by the Microsoft Graph reporting API. A user assigned to the Reports Reader role can access only relevant usage and adoption metrics. They don't have any admin permissions to configure settings or access the product specific admin centers like Exchange.

Question says : User1 can view Analytics & reports in the Microsoft Teams admin center

User with Reports reader role will get the following for admin.teams.microsoft.com - The account credentials you used to sign in aren't authorized to access this website. Make sure you're using the right account and that you have correct permissions.

Selected Answer: D
You can use Microsoft 365 usage analytics in Power BI to view and analyze usage data for Teams and other Microsoft 365 or Office 365 products and services. Microsoft 365 usage analytics is a content pack that includes a pre-built dashboard and a number of pre-built reports. Each report gives you specific usage data and insights. To connect to the content pack, you need Power BI and must be a global admin in Microsoft 365, Office 365, or reports reader. Ans: Reports Reader

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to prevent a user named User1 from permanently deleting private chats in Microsoft Teams.
Solution: You create an In-Place Hold for the Microsoft OneDrive for Business site of User1.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
B
MS OneDrive for Business is used for private items/files/folders that might be shared via private chats, but the private chats themselves are stored in a user's Exchange mailbox.

Selected Answer: B
Private chats are stored in private mailboxes
No, for me: Private chat is stored in private mailbox so it's in Exchange Online not OneDrive

Selected Answer: B
correct answer is B

Private chats are held in Azure Cosmos DB and are copied to user mailbox for retention and compliance. A litigation Hold on user’s mailbox is needed.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/121218/where-does-ms-teams-stores-our-1on1-conversations.html
Defo B - Needs mailbox

Taking a second look at this, this also would not prevent User1 from deleting anything, it would help the administrator prevent the chats from being deleted from the back end.
In Teams Admin Center, you could create a messaging policy, named user1, set the "delete sent messages" to off, and apply it to that user.
That would actually prevent the user from deleting, while not effecting anyone else.
Ans is no
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/legal-hold
Private chat is stored in private mailbox so it's in Exchange Online not OneDrive
Key words here are "for the MS OneDrive for Business" Hence answer is No (B)

For VDI, the base image needs to be updated. Basically, the parent image, is used for several VDI machines, you can update the machines, and when they are rebooted, they revert to the parent image, which is why this answer is B.

"Teams clients on Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) aren't automatically updated the way that non-VDI Teams clients are. You have to update the VM image by installing a new MSI as described in the instructions to Install Teams on VDI. You must uninstall the current version to update to a newer version."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-client-update#what-about-updates-to-teams-on-vdi
On Test 18.01.22
Will go for B after reading: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-client-update#what-about-updates-to-teams-on-vdi

Selected Answer: B
correct answer is B

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription and a Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) solution.
The company's Microsoft Teams upgrade policy is set to Teams only coexistence mode.
You deploy the Microsoft Installer (MSI) package for Microsoft Teams to the VDI solution.
Several months later, users of the VDI solution report that their workstation is missing several new Microsoft Teams features.
You need to ensure that the VDI solution users can use the new Microsoft Teams features.
Solution: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, you modify the Microsoft Teams upgrade policy.
Does this meet the goal?

choices.A: From the Microsoft 365 Compliance admin center, create a data loss prevention (DLP) policy.
choices.B: From the Azure Active Directory admin center, enable the End user protection baseline policy.
choices.D: From the Azure Active Directory admin center, add an identity provider.
choices.C: From the Microsoft 365 Compliance admin center, select Turn on Defender for Office 365 for SharePoint, OneDrive, and Microsoft Teams.

discussion.content:

https://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-700/view/23/

comments.content: Turn On Microsoft 365 Defender via Microsoft 365 security center: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender/m365d-enable?view=o365-worldwide

However, the answer is not 100% correct, at least now. Microsoft 365 compliance does not provide access to Threat management console. You should use Office 365 Security & Compliance instead.
Microsoft 365 admin center > Security > LogIn into > Office 365 Security & Compliance > Threat Management > Policy > Safe Attachments > Create (Safe Attachments policy)

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.
You enable guest access for Microsoft Teams.
You need to prevent all users from downloading and opening files that contain malware by using Microsoft Teams channels.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
I would say:
- Support Engineer
- Communication Admin
- Teams Admin

comments.content:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#teams-roles-and-capabilities
I agree

The correct answer is 
- Support specialist
- Communication Admin
- Teams Admin
The reason why first option is "Specialist" instead of "Engineer" is the specialist role is having least priviledge than engineer. Ref # https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#teams-roles-and-capabilities
I thought that the specialist cannot see metrics ?

Correct!
Support specialist; Access user profile page for troubleshooting calls in Call Analytics. Can only view user information for the specific user being searched for

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#teams-roles-and-capabilities

Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the ***users*** who are impacted by poor call quality.
L33D is correct but forgot to specify that this is the definition for Support ENGINEER.

On Test 29.03.22

Teams communications support specialist - limited view of per-user call analytics

Give permission to support and helpdesk staff
As the Teams admin, you have full access to call analytics information for all users. We've created some specialized Azure Active Directory roles that you can assign to support staff and helpdesk agents so they can also access per-user call analytics (without having access to the rest of the Teams admin center). Assign the Teams communications support specialist role to users who should have a limited view of per-user call analytics (Tier 1 support). Assign the Teams communications support engineer role to users who need full access to per-user call analytics (Tier 2 support). Neither role has access to the rest of the Teams admin center.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/set-up-call-analytics

comments.content:
The Teams communications support specialist (Tier 1 support) handles basic call-quality problems. They don't investigate issues with meetings. Instead, they collect related information and then escalate to a Teams communications support engineer.

The Teams communications support engineer (Tier 2 support) sees information in detailed call logs that are hidden from the Teams communications support specialist. The table below lists the information available to each Teams communication support role.
Did you choose Supp. Engineer or Specialist? ;-)

Note that the question state that "The solution must use the principle of least privilege."
1.)Teams Communications Support Specialist - Will be suffice for troubleshooting calls in Call Analytics.
2.)Teams Communications Administrator - Manage meetings, including meeting policies, configurations, and conference bridges.
3.)Teams Administrator - Only the Teams Administrator can Publish apps to the tenant app catalog in the Microsoft Teams admin center.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#teams-roles-and-capabilities

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Your company has a Microsoft Office 365 subscription.
The company has the administrators and the security requirements shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to assign a role to each administrator to ensure that the administrators can meet the security requirements by using the Microsoft Teams admin center.
The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to each administrator? To answer, drag the appropriate roles to the correct users. Each role may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
